text:
Fast fashion has led to a massive surge in cheap, plastic-based clothing, and a lot of it is secretly dumped in the Global South, especially Kenya. Even though waste export is restricted in many places, millions of unsellable synthetic garments—often damaged or unwearable—are shipped there every year, ending up in landfills, rivers, or burned as toxic fuel. Big brands like H&M and Old Navy are among the culprits, and even “recycling” companies are major contributors. This isn’t just waste—it’s pollution, harming people and ecosystems. We can’t recycle our way out of this. Fast fashion needs real accountability, from better design to stronger regulations.

authorMeta.name: nibarguen
text:
El fast fashion ha transformado la industria de la moda en una máquina de sobreproducción y consumo desmedido, llevando a una crisis ambiental y social global. Cada año, se producen alrededor de 100,000 millones de prendas, muchas de las cuales terminan como desechos en países del sur global. En lugares como Ghana, que es solo un ejemplo, millones de prendas de baja calidad son importadas, causando una enorme acumulación de ropa que no puede ser revendida. Este exceso de textiles no solo ocupa mercados informales, sino que también termina contaminando el aire, el agua y el suelo, liberando sustancias químicas tóxicas y microplásticos que dañan ecosistemas completos. La quema de estas prendas genera emisiones de gases peligrosos y las fibras sintéticas que las componen se descomponen en partículas que afectan la vida marina.

El problema no termina en Ghana, países como India, Pakistán y Haití también sufren las consecuencias de la moda rápida. Las marcas de moda globales, que continúan promoviendo una cultura de consumo rápido, deben asumir la responsabilidad por los impactos de sus prácticas. Es urgente que repensemos nuestros hábitos de consumo y que las políticas globales incluyan la responsabilidad extendida del productor, fomentando la sostenibilidad y el reciclaje. Solo así podremos mitigar los efectos devastadores del fast fashion en nuestro planeta.

💰 El salario mínimo en la industria textil de Bangladesh es de 8.300 takas al mes (aproximadamente 70€), pero incluso con horas extra muchas personas no llegan a cubrir sus necesidades básicas.

🔥 Condiciones laborales: En 2013, la tragedia del Rana Plaza, donde murieron más de 1.100 trabajadores por el derrumbe de un edificio de fábricas textiles, mostró al mundo la realidad de la moda rápida. A más de 10 años, las condiciones siguen siendo precarias en muchos casos.

🌍 La moda ética es posible: Como consumidores, podemos elegir ropa de segunda mano, marcas con certificaciones éticas o iniciativas de economía solidaria que respeten los derechos de las personas y del planeta.

OR: change the material for the patch, or keep it leather to make sure it's the same color / doesn't bleed!!!

You may know Fabletics as Kate Hudson’s cute activewear brand. It was co-founded by Adam Goldenberg and Don Ressler, a Silicon Valley duo that was behind Sensa, a fake weight-loss product that was fined $26 million by the FTC for deceptive advertising.

They now run TechStyle Fashion Group, the parent company of Fabletics and Savage X Fenty. In 2022, TechStyle got wrapped up in a $1.2 million lawsuit for quietly enrolling customers into Rihanna’s Savage X Fenty’ VIP memberships without consent. Many of the brands that are affiliated with TechStyle are based on subscriptions.

Beyond that, import records show that Fabletics is linked to factories accused of toxic waste dumping, SA and forced labor. Reports have surfaced from Indonesia, Jordan, Lesotho, and Sri Lanka, naming suppliers like Classic Fashion, Mas Holdings, and PT Sansan Saudaratex.

Watchdogs have also called out Fabletics for having clothing that tested around 40x higher than the legal limit of BPA, a chemical linked to hormone disruption.

authorMeta.name: sambentley
text:
If you wear a lot of black clothing you’ll want to hear this, because the fashion industry has been hiding something from us.

Most black clothing is dyed with pigments made from fossil fuels. The most common is called carbon black, a byproduct of burning petroleum or coal.

Not only does this produce CO₂ and release toxic particles into the air, but carbon black is also considered a possible human carcinogen by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC).

And studies suggest that prolonged exposure to carbon black particles in the air can impact respiratory health.

But there’s now a much better solution.

US-based Living Ink has found a way to create this deep black colour from algae!

First the algae grows, they then collects its natural pigments, and they heat-treat them to create the black colouring.

The result is a non-toxic alternative, without the environmental or health risks.

And big brands are already using it!
If more people knew about this, we’d see it in way more products and it'd help push us away from harmful fossil fuels.

So share this video to help spread the word.

#goodnews #fastfashion #sustainability #pollution #sustainableliving

Style has nothing to do with the price point of your clothing! That being said, I’ve found that taking one giant step back from fast fashion has helped me elevate my wardrobe tremendously.

I was around 24 years old and moving from London to NY when I had to go through all of my clothes to decide what I’d move with me. I realized I had amassed a series of ‘going out’ outfits from Zara, Topshop, ASOS, etc. that served their purposes for the month but weren’t pieces I loved and they certainly weren’t timeless. After this epiphany, I started getting really serious about investing in luxury fashion but of course had to do it on a budget. 

Designer consignment shops (especially the ones on the UES in a Manhattan), The Real Real, eBay and designer outlets have become my holy grail for shopping. The thrill of buying luxury items that you’ll have forever at an accessible price point is so satisfying.

authorMeta.name: theplacesbetweenus
text:
Fast Fashion hat nicht nur die Modewelt, sondern auch den globalen Textilhandel verändert – und das oft mit negativen Folgen. 

Ghana, der zweitgrößte Importeur von Altkleidern, spürt das deutlich: Rund 15 Millionen Kleidungsstücke treffen jede Woche auf Märkten wie dem Kantamanto-Markt ein und werden von dort in ganz Westafrika weiterverkauft. Doch die überwältigende Menge und die schlechte Qualität von Ultra-Fast-Fashion-Artikeln überschwemmen den Markt.

Bis zu 60 % der Ware wird aussortiert und landet auf Müllhalden oder im Meer, wo sie die Umwelt mit Mikroplastik und verbranntem Polyester verschmutzt. Vor der Küste Accras ziehen Fischer täglich Unmengen an Textilmüll aus dem Wasser.

💡Was könnten wir tun?

👉Minderwertige Kleidung besteuern:
Produkte aus schlecht recycelbaren Materialien sollten stärker besteuert werden, um die teuren Entsorgungs- und Recyclingprozesse zu finanzieren. Dies könnte auch den Anreiz für Unternehmen erhöhen, nachhaltigere Materialien zu verwenden.

👉Nachhaltige Materialien fördern:
Die Produktion und der Einsatz von biologisch abbaubaren Textilien wie Bananatex sollten aktiv unterstützt und gefördert werden. Diese Materialien zersetzen sich, ohne die Umwelt zu belasten.

👉Beteiligung der betroffenen Länder stärken:
Länder wie Ghana, die am meisten mit dem Textilmüll zu kämpfen haben, sollten in internationale Entscheidungs- und Besteuerungsprozesse stärker einbezogen werden. So könnten sie nicht nur von den Einnahmen profitieren, sondern auch ihre eigenen Abfallmanagementsysteme stärken.

👉Bewusstsein schaffen: Marken und Initiativen, die sich für Recycling und Upcycling einsetzen, wie @theorispresent und @therevivalbrand, sollten stärker gefördert werden und mehr internationale Aufmerksamkeit bekommen. Sie bieten Lösungen vor Ort an und tragen zur Verbesserung der Situation bei.

Und vor allem müssen wir endlich in Kreislaufwirtschaften denken und arbeiten, egal in welcher Branche. Wir denken in so vielen Bereichen nur bis zum Verkauf und nicht bis zum Ende.

It’s all about consumption habits ppl 💬 let’s break it down: 

why is fast fashion such a large industry? becaude it relies on people purchasing micro trends over and over again. I think you could argue that fast fashion brands create the demand so that we continue to buy. And in many cases, these fast fashion giants will cut corners to get a lower cost which is why you see:

👉cheap synthetic fabrics + construction AND
👉garment workers not getting paid fairly

The fast fashion industry is a problem, and it’s fueled by overconsumption. That’s why I will argue that people buying fast fashion out of necessity (OR buying a few pieces that they know they will wear for a long time) is a way more sustainable purchase than overconsuming a bunch of secondhand fashion that only gets worn a few times (and yes, I’m guilty of this). 

We need to change how we consume clothing, just as much as the fast fashion brands need to change how they produce. 

What do you think?

text:
Alcuni attivisti di Extinction Rebellion si sono sdraiati in segno di protesta di fronte al pop up store di Shein a Parigi, bloccando il traffico. L’obiettivo di ER era «​​denunciare l'impatto sociale, ecologico e sulla salute della multinazionale» e convincere le persone a non acquistare nel negozio temporaneo del marchio cinese di moda online, simbolo del fast fashion.

Shein è diventato popolare per i bassi prezzi dei suoi prodotti e per il suo catalogo immenso. Il marchio cinese è però finito al centro di polemiche per l'impatto ambientale della sua produzione e per le accuse di sfruttamento dei lavoratori. Lo scorso autunno l’inchiesta “Untold: Inside the Shein Machine”, realizzata dalla reporter Iman Amrani con Zandland Films, e mandata in onda da All4, la pay-tv del canale britannico Channel4, ha raccontato l’ipersfruttamento del marchio cinese nei confronti della manodopera, costretta a lavorare anche 18 ore al giorno.

Dal canto suo, l’azienda ha sempre dichiarato di avvalersi di agenzie terze per verificare il rispetto delle leggi e degli standard lavorativi.

Secondo un rapporto delle Nazioni Unite, l'industria della moda produce dall'8% al 10% di tutte le emissioni globali di CO2, immettendo ogni anno tra i 4 e 5 miliardi di tonnellate di anidride carbonica in atmosfera.

The True Cost Of Quiet Luxury ~
Fast fashion is notorious for worker exploitation within the fashion supply chain, but there are countless examples of luxury brands using the same harmful labour practices. This is why we must shift the dial from solely critiquing fast fashion and instead focus on ~Big Fashion~  According to Bloomberg’s unmissable report into Loro Piana, the brand has done next to nothing for the indigenous community whose skilled labour they have relied on for the past 30 years. In fact, 80% of the community feel that they have not been fairly compensated.  We must continue to organise in solidarity with workers and their unions in a bid to create a fashion system that benefits everybody in the supply chain, irrespective of how ‘luxury’ a brand’s reputation is.   Resources:  The Vicuñas And The $9,000 Sweater [Bloomberg]

Is Massimo Dutti Quiet Luxury or Just Quietly Fast Fashion? 

Did you know there’s no actual Massimo Dutti? It’s not Italian, it’s not artisanal, and it’s owned by Inditex—yes, the same parent company as Zara. 

Massimo Dutti mastered the art of 'Italian sounding' marketing, offering the illusion of luxury without the craftsmanship.

About 10 years ago, it was the go-to for young professionals wanting tailored style on a budget. Today It’s for the fashion lovers chasing the quiet luxury aesthetic

While some pieces are better quality than typical fast fashion, it’s mass-produced, and far from premium quality.

And yet, some luxury brands sell pieces of similar quality for €1K

So, the question arises… who’s the jerk here?

It’s all about consumption habits ppl 💬 let’s break it down: 

why is fast fashion such a large industry? becaude it relies on people purchasing micro trends over and over again. I think you could argue that fast fashion brands create the demand so that we continue to buy. And in many cases, these fast fashion giants will cut corners to get a lower cost which is why you see:

👉cheap synthetic fabrics + construction AND
👉garment workers not getting paid fairly

The fast fashion industry is a problem, and it’s fueled by overconsumption. That’s why I will argue that people buying fast fashion out of necessity (OR buying a few pieces that they know they will wear for a long time) is a way more sustainable purchase than overconsuming a bunch of secondhand fashion that only gets worn a few times (and yes, I’m guilty of this). 

We need to change how we consume clothing, just as much as the fast fashion brands need to change how they produce. 

What do you think?

Your friendly reminder that hands are behind every single piece of clothing you wear. It’s important to know where your clothing is coming from, the conditions of workers, and materials used for creation. Be INTENTIONAL, MINDFUL, and start CARING about what you put on your body. There’s a story behind every single piece. 

These videos are from the Dharavi “slums” in Mumbai, India. Much of there work produced is for major fast fashion companies that you could probably guess the names of … these conditions are dangerous and unfair. Stop supporting big brands who aren’t transparent about their workers. 

Hard to explain how it felt walking into these rooms. A mixture of major guilt and helplessness. They work 12-15 hour days for little money to support their families and survive. They are constantly around harsh chemicals from dyes, leathers, and fabric scraps- their life is not worth a new shirt!!! 

*I did get permission to film all these videos 

#fastfashion #travelwithme #traveltheworld #lifestyle #sustainablefashion

Your friendly reminder that hands are behind every single piece of clothing you wear. It’s important to know where your clothing is coming from, the conditions of workers, and materials used for creation. Be INTENTIONAL, MINDFUL, and start CARING about what you put on your body. There’s a story behind every single piece. 

These videos are from the Dharavi “slums” in Mumbai, India. Much of there work produced is for major fast fashion companies that you could probably guess the names of … these conditions are dangerous and unfair. Stop supporting big brands who aren’t transparent about their workers. 

Hard to explain how it felt walking into these rooms. A mixture of major guilt and helplessness. They work 12-15 hour days for little money to support their families and survive. They are constantly around harsh chemicals from dyes, leathers, and fabric scraps- their life is not worth a new shirt!!! 

*I did get permission to film all these videos 

#fastfashion #travelwithme #traveltheworld #lifestyle #sustainablefashion
